block.p: Pakistani Forces Fire On Indian Aircraft Pakistan fired a surface-to-air missile at Indian aircraft, keeping tensions between the neighbors at a high boil. The missile, which missed its target, was aimed in the direction of jet fighters and helicopters flying near the wreckage of a Pakistani plane shot down on Tuesday.

Pakistani Forces Fire On Indian Aircraft Pakistan fired a surface-to-air missile at Indian aircraft, keeping tensions between the neighbors at a high boil. The missile, which missed its target, was aimed in the direction of jet fighters and helicopters flying near the wreckage of a Pakistani plane shot down on Tuesday.

Rebel Claims Role in Caucasus Shamil Basayev, a Chechen who is leading guerrillas in the Caucasus, said he was active in the rebellion that has flared up in Dagestan, and that he wanted to drive Russian forces from the region.

Cambodia War Crimes Tribunal The United Nations has developed plans for a joint war crimes tribunal in Cambodia in which Cambodian and foreign judges would try former leaders of the Khmer Rouge in a single trial, United Nations and American officials said. United Nations lawyers came up with the plan after the Cambodian Government rejected an earlier proposal to try Pol Pot's former associates in a fully independent international tribunal.

Law Extended to U.N. Troops Secretary General Kofi Annan ordered all forces operating under the organization's command to abide by international laws protecting civilians and governing the conduct of soldiers in war, overriding objections from a number of countries that contribute peacekeeping troops.

Effort Against Poverty The United Nations Development Program and Cisco Systems, a maker of data communications gear, have enlisted popular entertainers to kick off an Internet-based initiative to help relieve global poverty.

Church Urges Serbs to Resign Serbian Orthodox bishops appealed to President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia and Serbia's President, Milan Milutinovic, to resign and make room for others who could save the country from destruction. They also called for a transitional government and early elections.

Ecuador's Leader Visits Peru President Jamil Mahuad arrived in Lima on an official visit intended to improve commercial relations between Ecuador and Peru. It is the first visit by an Ecuadorean head of state since the two nations resolved a 150-year-old border dispute in October.

Suspect in Mass Shooting Surrenders to the F.B.I. Buford O. Furrow, a white supremacist suspected of shooting and wounding five people at a Jewish community center in Los Angeles, turned himself in to the F.B.I., saying he wanted the attack to send a message to the nation, officials said. He will also be charged with the murder of a letter carrier near the center.
Youth to Be Tried as Adult A judge ordered T. J. Solomon, 15, to be tried as an adult in the nonfatal shootings of six classmates at Heritage High School in Conyers, Ga.
Kansas Drops Evolution The Kansas Board of Education voted to delete virtually any mention of evolution from state science curriculums, in one of the most far-reaching efforts by creationists.
Deadly Tornado in Utah A tornado that struck downtown Salt Lake City killed at least one person and injured more than 60.

Clinton Commutes Sentences President Clinton agreed to commute the sentences of 16 members of a Puerto Rican nationalist group that was involved in more than 100 bombings of political and military installations in the United States.
Customs to Alter Search Rules The Customs Service, facing suits asserting racial bias in body searches for drugs, announced a revamping of guidelines for inspectors.

No Indictments Expected An independent counsel was said to have concluded that there is insufficient evidence to seek indictments in an inquiry into Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt's role in the rejection of an Indian casino application.
Guarding Against Airline Fires The F.A.A. said it would propose modifications on 700 large jets to remove insulation that is covered with a material that can spread small sparks into fatal fires.
Effort to Replace Fossil Fuels President Clinton will announce a long-term effort today to help replace coal, oil, natural gas and uranium with farm products, crop wastes and trees.
Actor Mulls Candidacy Warren Beatty, expressing displeasure with Al Gore and Bill Bradley, said he was considering running for President next year.

New Jersey High Court Affirms Death Sentence The New Jersey Supreme Court, voting 4 to 3, upheld the death sentence imposed on Jesse Timmendequas, who was convicted of raping and murdering 7-year-old Megan Kanka in 1994. The Court said the deluge of pretrial publicity surrounding the case had not unfairly prejudiced jurors against the defendant. Mr. Timmendequas, 37, has several more avenues for appeal, which are expected to take years to complete.

Errors Cost Giuliani Campaign Mayor Giuliani's fund-raising committee returned $57,000 in donations because of technical mistakes and election law violations. That was more than half the total raised at a New Jersey developer's party.
Housing Homeless in Hospitals The Giuliani administration wants to use rooms at two hospitals to house homeless families overnight, but the plan drew quick opposition.
Poisoning of Birds Suspected Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern said intentional poisoning was suspected in the deaths of nearly four dozen birds found dead in Central Park on Tuesday and yesterday.
Squalls Rock Long Island Parts of Suffolk County were inundated by sudden downpours and buffeted by high winds, but no serious injuries were reported.
Sidekick to Go It Alone Andy Richter, Conan O'Brien's sidekick on NBC's ''Late Night,'' will leave the show next spring.

Knicks Introduce New G.M. Dave Checketts, the Madison Square Garden president, said he had hired Scott Layden away from the Utah Jazz to become the Knicks' general manager largely because of his insight and ability to spot talent.

Alcoa Has Merger Plans, Too Alcoa, the world's largest aluminum producer, said it wanted to buy Reynolds Metals, a troubled competitor that is nonetheless the industry's third largest producer. Reynolds said its board would study the offer. The announcement came a day after three big rivals to Alcoa said they would merge to create Alcan, a $21.6 billion behemoth.

Airline Chief Fighting Cancer The chairman and chief executive of Southwest Airlines, Herbert D. Kelleher, 68, told employees that he would have eight weeks of radiation treatment for prostate cancer but would regularly be in the office.
P.& G. Buys Pet Food Company Procter & Gamble said it would acquire Iams, the premium pet food maker, for $2.3 billion, putting Procter & Gamble atop the high end of the $25 billion pet food market.
Bid for Hispanic Market Telefonica of Spain was said to have agreed to form a venture with IDT to market telephone and Internet services to Spanish-speakers in the United States and Latin America.
Fed: Inflation Still at Bay The economy is expanding with little sign of inflation, the Fed said, taking the edge off investor concern over further interest rates increases.
